segments.text: There is no use your telling me that you are going to be good. You are quite perfect. Pray, don’t change.
segments.voice_traits: Refined, aristocratic accent; measured, deliberate pace; slight sarcasm with well-timed pauses.

segments.text: No, Harry, I have done too many dreadful things in my life. I am not going to do any more. I began my good actions yesterday.
segments.voice_traits: Soft and reflective tone; measured pace with a hint of inner turmoil; gentle, trembling undercurrent.

segments.text: Where were you yesterday?
segments.voice_traits: Energetic and inquisitive with crisp enunciation; refined accent with a playful lilt.

segments.text: In the country, Harry. I was staying at a little inn by myself.
segments.voice_traits: Measured, reflective tone; soft enunciation and deliberate pacing.

segments.text: My dear boy, anybody can be good in the country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not by any means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they stagnate.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth, sardonic tone with deliberate phrasing; measured emphasis on key words and a refined, ironic accent.

segments.text: Culture and corruption. I have known something of both. It seems terrible to me now that they should ever be found together. For I have a new ideal, Harry. I am going to alter. I think I have altered.
segments.voice_traits: Steady and reflective tone with clear enunciation and deliberate pacing.

segments.text: You have not yet told me what your good action was. Or did you say you had done more than one?
segments.voice_traits: Light-hearted and teasing with a precise, aristocratic accent and a playful cadence.

segments.text: I can tell you, Harry. It is not a story I could tell to anyone else. I spared somebody. It sounds vain, but you understand what I mean. She was quite beautiful and wonderfully like Sibyl Vane. I think it was that which first attracted me to her. You remember Sibyl, don’t you? How long ago that seems! Well, Hetty was not one of our own class, of course. She was simply a girl in a village. But I really loved her. I am quite sure that I loved her. All during this wonderful May that we have been having, I used to run down and see her two or three times a week. Yesterday she met me in a little orchard. The apple-blossoms kept tumbling down on her hair, and she was laughing. We were to have gone away together this morning at dawn. Suddenly I determined to leave her as flowerlike as I had found her.
segments.voice_traits: Gentle and reflective tone with soft enunciation; lingering pauses on emotional phrases and a subtle air of regret.

segments.text: I should think the novelty of the emotion must have given you a thrill of real pleasure, Dorian. But I can finish your idyll for you. You gave her good advice and broke her heart. That was the beginning of your reformation.
segments.voice_traits: Dry wit in an arch tone; deliberate, measured pacing with playful emphasis.

segments.text: Harry, you are horrible! You mustn’t say these dreadful things. Hetty’s heart is not broken. Of course, she cried and all that. But there is no disgrace upon her. She can live, like Perdita, in her garden of mint and marigold.
segments.voice_traits: Strained, emphatic tone with a slight tremor; heartfelt and forceful delivery.

segments.text: And weep over a faithless Florizel. My dear Dorian, you have the most curiously boyish moods. Do you think this girl will ever be really content now with any one of her own rank? I suppose she will be married some day to a rough carter or a grinning ploughman. Well, the fact of having met you, and loved you, will teach her to despise her husband, and she will be wretched. From a moral point of view, I cannot say that I think much of your great renunciation. Even as a beginning, it is poor. Besides, how do you know that Hetty isn’t floating at the present moment in some starlit mill-pond, with lovely water-lilies round her, like Ophelia?
segments.voice_traits: Conversational with a lightly humorous and sardonic inflection; upbeat and rhythmic pacing.

segments.text: I can’t bear this, Harry! You mock at everything, and then suggest the most serious tragedies. I am sorry I told you now. I don’t care what you say to me. I know I was right in acting as I did. Poor Hetty! As I rode past the farm this morning, I saw her white face at the window, like a spray of jasmine. Don’t let us talk about it any more, and don’t try to persuade me that the first good action I have done for years, the first little bit of self-sacrifice I have ever known, is really a sort of sin. I want to be better. I am going to be better. Tell me something about yourself. What is going on in town? I have not been to the club for days.
segments.voice_traits: Intense and passionate delivery with a slightly rushed pace; clear articulation and firm emphasis.

segments.text: The people are still discussing poor Basil’s disappearance.
segments.voice_traits: Dry humorous tone with measured pacing and aristocratic cadence.

segments.text: I should have thought they had got tired of that by this time.
segments.voice_traits: Casual tone with a wry inflection; reflective pauses as he pours wine.

segments.text: My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public are really not equal to the mental strain of having more than one topic every three months. They have been very fortunate lately, however. They have had my own divorce-case and Alan Campbell’s suicide. Now they have got the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the grey ulster who left for Paris by the midnight train on the ninth of November was poor Basil, and the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris at all. I suppose in about a fortnight we shall be told that he has been seen in San Francisco. It is an odd thing, but every one who disappears is said to be seen at San Francisco. It must be a delightful city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.
segments.voice_traits: Storytelling tone with articulate phrasing; slightly ironic and measured pace with urbane accent.

segments.text: What do you think has happened to Basil?
segments.voice_traits: Gentle and inquisitive tone with soft enunciation and a reflective pause.

segments.text: I have not the slightest idea. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it is no business of mine. If he is dead, I don’t want to think about him. Death is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.
segments.voice_traits: Confessional tone with measured pace and clear articulation, hinting at an underlying fear.

segments.text: Why?
segments.voice_traits: Short, questioning tone with soft enunciation and a hint of fatigue.

segments.text: Because, one can survive everything nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two facts in the nineteenth century that one cannot explain away. Let us have our coffee in the music-room, Dorian. You must play Chopin to me. The man with whom my wife ran away played Chopin exquisitely. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house is rather lonely without her. Of course, married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the loss even of one’s worst habits. Perhaps one regrets them the most. They are such an essential part of one’s personality.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth and refined tone; gentle persuasion with thoughtful pauses and a measured, urbane cadence.

segments.text: Dorian falls silent. He rises from the table, crosses into the next room, and sits at the piano. His fingers stray across the ivory keys as soft music fills the air. Coffee is brought in, and with a hesitant glance at Lord Henry, he speaks:
segments.voice_traits: Calm, descriptive narration; clear, smooth articulation with gentle pacing.

segments.text: Harry, did it ever occur to you that Basil was murdered?
segments.voice_traits: Measured tone with a hint of uncertainty; clear and deliberate enunciation.

segments.text: Basil was very popular, and always wore a Waterbury watch. Why should he have been murdered? He was not clever enough to have enemies. Of course, he had a wonderful genius for painting. But a man can paint like Velasquez and yet be as dull as possible. Basil was really rather dull. He only interested me once, and that was when he told me, years ago, that he had a wild adoration for you and that you were the dominant motive of his art.
segments.voice_traits: Dry, measured tone with articulate phrasing and a subtle ironic undercurrent.

segments.text: I was very fond of Basil. But don’t people say that he was murdered?
segments.voice_traits: Soft, melancholic tone; gentle pauses with a subdued, introspective cadence.

segments.text: Oh, some of the papers do. It does not seem to me to be at all probable. I know there are dreadful places in Paris, but Basil was not the sort of man to have gone to them. He had no curiosity. It was his chief defect.
segments.voice_traits: Observant tone with precise enunciation; slightly critical inflection and measured pacing.

segments.text: What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had murdered Basil?
segments.voice_traits: Cool, deliberate tone; slightly challenging with a measured pace and clear articulation.

segments.text: I would say, my dear fellow, that you were posing for a character that doesn’t suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime. It is not in you, Dorian, to commit a murder. I am sorry if I hurt your vanity by saying so, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower orders. I don’t blame them in the smallest degree. I should fancy that crime was to them what art is to us, simply a method of procuring extraordinary sensations.
segments.voice_traits: Refined, arch tone with deliberate pacing and playful condescension.

segments.text: A method of procuring sensations? Do you think, then, that a man who has once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again? Don’t tell me that.
segments.voice_traits: Sharp, questioning tone; crisp enunciation with moderate, deliberate pacing.

segments.text: Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often. That is one of the most important secrets of life. I should fancy, however, that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner. But let us pass from poor Basil. I wish I could believe that he had come to such a really romantic end as you suggest, but I can’t. I dare say he fell into the Seine off an omnibus and that the conductor hushed up the scandal. Yes, I should fancy that was his end. I see him lying now on his back under those dull-green waters, with heavy barges floating above and long weeds catching in his hair. Do you know, I don’t think he would have done much more good work. During the last ten years his painting had gone off very much.
segments.voice_traits: Light-hearted irony with a relaxed tone; thoughtful pauses and measured, reflective pacing.

segments.text: Dorian heaves a sigh. Lord Henry strolls across the room and, in a leisurely manner, strokes the head of a curious Java parrot—a large grey-plumaged bird with a pink crest and tail resting on a bamboo perch. The parrot sways gently as delicate white particulates fall from its eyes.
segments.voice_traits: Descriptive, smooth narration with gentle pacing and clear, deliberate phrasing.

segments.text: Yes, his painting had quite gone off. It seemed to me to have lost something. It had lost an ideal. When you and he ceased to be great friends, he ceased to be a great artist. What was it that separated you? I suppose he bored you. If so, he never forgave you. It’s a habit of bores. By the way, what has become of that wonderful portrait he did of you? I don’t think I have ever seen it since he finished it. Oh! I remember you telling me years ago that you had sent it down to Selby, and that it had got mislaid or stolen on the way. You never got it back? What a pity! It was really a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had now. It belonged to Basil’s best period. Since then, his work was that curious mixture of bad painting and good intentions that always entitles a man to be called a representative British artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.
segments.voice_traits: Aristocratic and lightly amused tone; thoughtful pauses with reflective cadence and clear articulation.

segments.text: I forget. I suppose I did. But I never really liked it. I am sorry I sat for it. The memory of the thing is hateful to me. Why do you talk of it? It used to remind me of those curious lines in some play—Hamlet, I think—how do they run? 'Like the painting of a sorrow, a face without a heart.' Yes: that is what it was like.
segments.voice_traits: Reflective and slightly remorseful tone; measured, soft pacing with a dismissive inflection.

segments.text: If a man treats life artistically, his brain is his heart.
segments.voice_traits: Calm, pensive tone with a whisper-soft, concluding cadence; measured and reflective.

segments.text: ‘Like the painting of a sorrow, a face without a heart.’
segments.voice_traits: Calm and mellow tone with soft articulation and lingering emphasis.

segments.text: Lord Henry reclines in an arm-chair, his eyes half-closed. After a moment’s pause he addresses Dorian once more, posing a philosophical query about the soul.
segments.voice_traits: Thoughtful narration with a measured, reflective tone and gentle pacing.

segments.text: By the way, Dorian, what does it profit a man if he gain the whole world and lose—how does the quotation run?—his own soul?
segments.voice_traits: Mellow, reflective tone with careful pauses and a slight rising inflection on the rhetorical question.

segments.text: Why do you ask me that, Harry?
segments.voice_traits: Inquisitive tone with a steady pace and clear, measured stress on his words.

segments.text: My dear fellow, I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill, hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.
segments.voice_traits: Expressive and vivid tone with varying pacing; articulate urban accent with dramatic pauses.

segments.text: Don’t, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought, and sold, and bartered away. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is a soul in each one of us. I know it.
segments.voice_traits: Assertive tone with clear enunciation; forceful and deliberate with steady pacing.

segments.text: Do you feel quite sure of that, Dorian?
segments.voice_traits: Lightly mocking with an inquisitive cadence; clear and playful tone.

segments.text: Quite sure.
segments.voice_traits: Firm, concise tone with a measured, deliberate pace.

segments.text: Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one feels absolutely certain about are never true. That is the fatality of faith, and the lesson of romance. How grave you are! Don’t be so serious. What have you or I to do with the superstitions of our age? No: we have given up our belief in the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian, and, as you play, tell me in a low voice how you have kept your youth. You must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you are, and I am wrinkled, and worn, and yellow. You are really wonderful, Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do tonight. You remind me of the day I saw you first. You were rather cheeky, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To get back my youth I would do anything in the world—except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable. Youth! There is nothing like it. It’s absurd to talk of the ignorance of youth. The only people whose opinions I listen to now with any respect are people much younger than myself. They seem to be right in front of me. Life has revealed to them her latest wonder. As for the aged, I always contradict the aged. I do it on principle. If you ask them their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they solemnly give you the opinions current in 1820, when people wore high stocks, believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How lovely that thing you are playing is! I wonder, did Chopin write it at Majorca, with the sea weeping round the villa and the salt spray dashing against the panes? It is marvellously romantic. What a blessing that there is one art left to us that is not imitative! Don’t stop. I want music tonight. It seems to me that you are the young Apollo and that I am Marsyas listening to you. I have sorrows, Dorian, of my own, that even you know nothing of. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. I am sometimes amazed at my own sincerity. Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have had! You have drunk deeply of everything. You have crushed the grapes against your palate. Nothing has been hidden from you. And it has all been to you no more than the sound of music. It has not marred you. You are still the same.
segments.emotion: eager, nostalgic, playful, with a touch of bittersweet sentiment
segments.voice_traits: Effusive and animated tone with refined accent; varying pace with passionate emphasis and reflective pauses.

segments.text: I am not the same, Harry.
segments.voice_traits: Firm, quiet tone with measured pacing and a reflective undercurrent.

segments.text: Yes, you are the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be. Don’t spoil it by renunciations. At present you are a perfect type. Don’t make yourself incomplete. You are quite flawless now. You need not shake your head: you know you are. Besides, Dorian, don’t deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question of nerves, fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides itself and passion has its dreams. You may fancy yourself safe and strong. But a chance tone of colour in a room or a morning sky, a particular perfume you once loved that stirs subtle memories, a line from a forgotten poem you encountered again, a cadence from a piece of music you had stopped playing—Dorian, it is on things like these that our lives depend. Browning writes about that somewhere; yet our senses create the truth. There are moments when the scent of lilas blanc suddenly carries me back to the strangest month of my life. I wish I could change places with you. The world has cried out against us both, yet it has always worshipped you. It always will. You are the type of man this age is searching for, even as it fears to admit it. I am so glad you have never gone beyond yourself in art. Life has been your art; you have set yourself to music. Your days are your sonnets.
segments.voice_traits: Eloquent and reflective with a rich, flowing cadence; gentle inflection and a warmly persuasive tone.

segments.text: Yes, life has been exquisite, but I am not going to have the same life, Harry. And you must not say these extravagant things to me. You don’t know everything about me. I think if you did, even you would turn from me. You laugh. Don’t laugh.
segments.voice_traits: Quiet intensity in a careful, measured tone with reflective pauses and a touch of reproach.

segments.text: Why have you stopped playing, Dorian? Go back and give me the nocturne over again. Look at that great, honey-coloured moon hanging in the dusky air. She is waiting for you to charm her—and if you play, she will come closer to the earth. You won’t? Let us go to the club, then. It has been a charming evening, and we must end it charmingly. There’s someone at White’s who is dying to know you—young Lord Poole, Bournemouth’s eldest son. He’s already copied your neckties and begged me to introduce you. He is quite delightful and, in many ways, reminds me of you.
segments.voice_traits: Lively and persuasive tone with a charming accent; rhythmic pacing and enthusiastic, inviting inflections.

segments.text: I hope not, but I am tired tonight, Harry. I shan’t go to the club. It’s nearly eleven and I want to go to bed early.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, tired tone with deliberate, languid pacing and gentle enunciation.

segments.text: Do stay. You have never played so well as tonight. There was something in your touch that was simply wonderful—more expression than I have ever heard before.
segments.voice_traits: Warm, encouraging tone with articulate expression and gentle, measured emphasis.

segments.text: It is because I am going to be good. I am a little changed already.
segments.voice_traits: Bright, clear tone with subtle warmth; deliberate enunciation and a confident, forward pacing.

segments.text: You cannot change to me, Dorian. You and I will always be friends.
segments.voice_traits: Steady and calm tone with sincere delivery; measured pacing and an unhurried, aristocratic cadence.

segments.text: Yet you poisoned me with a book once. I should not forgive that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to anyone. It does harm.
segments.voice_traits: Sharp, clear tone with a hint of reproach; deliberate and measured pace with precise enunciation.

segments.text: My dear boy, you are really beginning to moralize. You’ll soon be going about like the converted, the revivalist, warning people against all the sins you’ve grown tired of. You are too delightful for that. Besides, it is no use. You and I are what we are and will always be. As for being poisoned by a book, there is no such thing. Art has no influence upon action—it annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books the world calls immoral expose its own shame. That’s all. But let’s not discuss literature. Come round tomorrow: I’m riding at eleven. We might even go together, and I’ll take you to lunch afterwards with Lady Branksome—a charming woman who wants your opinion on some tapestries she’s considering buying. Mind you come. Or shall we lunch with our little duchess? She says she never sees you these days. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I thought you would be. Her clever tongue gets on one’s nerves. In any case, be here at eleven.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth, urbane tone with light humor; rapid yet clear pacing and playful pauses with an inviting inflection.

segments.text: Must I really come, Harry?
segments.voice_traits: Hesitant tone with low volume; reflective inflection and a measured, uncertain pace.

segments.text: Certainly. The park is quite lovely now—I don’t think there have been such lilacs since the year I met you.
segments.voice_traits: Smooth and pleasant tone with a romantic cadence; gentle, persuasive delivery and soft emphasis.

segments.text: Very well. I shall be here at eleven. Good night, Harry.
segments.voice_traits: Soft and reflective tone with measured pacing and a lingering pause at the farewell.

segments.text: At the door Dorian hesitates, as if holding back unspoken words. Then with a quiet sigh, he leaves, the quiet click of the door marking both his tentative resolve and the bittersweet echo of past transgressions.
segments.voice_traits: Soft, conclusive narration delivered in a reflective, gentle tone with measured pauses.
